text: He only is my rock and my salvation; he is my defence; I shall not be greatly moved.
text_kjv: He only is my rock and my salvation; he is my defence; I shall not be greatly moved.
text_niv: He alone is my rock and my salvation;he is my fortress, I will never be shaken.
text_esv: He alone is my rock and my salvation, my fortress; I shall not be greatly shaken.
text_nlt: He alone is my rock and my salvation,my fortress where I will never be shaken.
text_msg: He's solid rock under my feet,breathing room for my soul,An impregnable castle:I'm set for life.
text_nasb: He only is my rock and my salvation, My stronghold; I shall not be greatly shaken.
context: Psalm 62 is attributed to David, likely written during a period of intense personal threat and political instability, possibly during Absalom's rebellion. The phrase 'to the choirmaster: according to Jeduthun' indicates it was intended for public worship and performed by the temple musicians under Jeduthun's direction, emphasizing its communal and liturgical significance. The term 'Selah' appears throughout the Psalm, acting as a musical interlude or a call for reflection, urging the listener to pause and deeply consider the statements made. In ancient Israel, rocks and fortresses were common symbols of protection and security. David, as a shepherd and later a king constantly facing enemies, would have been keenly aware of the importance of secure defensive positions. The imagery of God as a rock resonates strongly within the historical context of a land marked by rocky terrain and fortified settlements. David's personal experiences of betrayal, persecution, and near-death situations provide a backdrop of profound vulnerability, making his declaration of God as his only true refuge all the more powerful. The repeated use of 'only' in verse 2 reinforces the exclusivity of God's protection, contrasting with the unreliable nature of human allies and earthly defenses. The psalm underscores the futility of trusting in fleeting power or worldly possessions, pointing instead to the enduring stability and unchanging faithfulness of God.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 62:2 is a powerful statement of faith and trust in God's sovereignty and provision. 'He only is my rock' speaks to God's unwavering stability and strength. The rock represents permanence, a firm foundation upon which one can build and find safety. It contrasts sharply with the shifting sands of human alliances and the ephemeral nature of earthly power. 'My salvation' declares God as the source of deliverance from danger and ultimate rescue from spiritual death. It points to the redemptive work of God, not just in immediate circumstances but also in the broader context of eternal life. 'He is my defense' underscores God's active protection against enemies, both physical and spiritual. It highlights God's role as a shield, a fortress, and a defender against those who seek to harm us. 'I shall not be greatly moved' expresses the confidence that arises from trusting in God. It doesn't promise a life free from trials or challenges but assures us that with God as our anchor, we will not be utterly defeated or shaken to our core. The phrase indicates a resilience and inner peace that transcends circumstances. The repetition of 'He' emphasizes God's personal involvement in David's life and, by extension, in the lives of all who trust in Him. Itâ€™s a testament to a relationship built on faith and experience. This verse encapsulates the core message of the psalm: true security and lasting peace are found only in God.
application: In modern life, Psalm 62:2 provides a powerful antidote to anxiety and fear in a world characterized by constant change, uncertainty, and multiple pressures. Consider how often we seek security in things that are ultimately unstable: financial investments, career advancement, relationships, or physical health. This verse calls us to re-evaluate our sources of security and to place our primary trust in God. Practically, this means cultivating a deeper relationship with God through regular prayer, scripture reading, and worship. When facing difficult situations, instead of immediately turning to worldly solutions, pause and remember that God is your rock, your salvation, and your defense. Visualize God as a strong fortress, providing protection and stability in the midst of the storm. Use this verse as a personal affirmation. Repeat it to yourself when you feel overwhelmed or anxious, reminding yourself of God's unwavering presence and power. Reflect on past experiences where God has demonstrated His faithfulness in your life. This can strengthen your trust and confidence in His ability to protect and deliver you in current challenges. Share this verse with others who are struggling with anxiety or fear. It can be a source of comfort and encouragement to know that they are not alone and that God is a refuge for all who seek Him. Explore ways to serve others and contribute to a more just and compassionate world. This can help you to shift your focus from your own anxieties to the needs of others, fostering a sense of purpose and connection. Finally, remember that being 'not greatly moved' doesn't mean that you won't experience emotions or challenges. It means that you won't be completely overwhelmed by them, because your hope and trust are firmly rooted in God's unchanging love and power.
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank you for being my rock, my salvation, and my defense. In a world filled with uncertainty and fear, I choose to place my trust in you. Forgive me for the times when I have sought security in things that are fleeting and unreliable. Help me to cultivate a deeper relationship with you, so that I may experience your peace and strength in all circumstances. When anxiety and fear threaten to overwhelm me, remind me of your unwavering presence and power. I declare that you are my refuge and my fortress, the One in whom I can always trust. Grant me the grace to be 'not greatly moved' by the challenges I face, knowing that you are with me always. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: Why does the verse say 'He *only* is my rock'? It emphasizes the exclusivity of God's role as our true source of security and salvation. It highlights that no other person, possession, or situation can ultimately provide the stability and protection we need; only God can.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse

faqs.answer: What does it mean to be 'greatly moved'? Being 'greatly moved' refers to being completely overwhelmed and destabilized by life's challenges. It suggests a loss of hope, faith, and inner peace, resulting in a state of fear and anxiety. Psalm 62:2 promises a protection against this state.
faqs.question: Q2

faqs.answer: How can I practically make God my 'rock' in daily life? By prioritizing your relationship with God through prayer, Bible study, and worship. Consciously turn to Him in times of trouble, trusting in His promises and seeking His guidance. Live a life that reflects His values.
faqs.question: Q3

faqs.answer: Does this verse mean I will never face hardship? No, it doesn't. It means that even in the midst of hardship, you will not be completely destroyed or shaken to your core. God's presence and protection will sustain you and give you strength to endure.
faqs.question: Q4

faqs.answer: How is God my 'salvation' in a practical sense? God offers salvation from sin and its consequences. Practically, this manifests as forgiveness, inner healing, guidance, and the hope of eternal life. Experiencing this helps navigate daily life with grace and purpose.
faqs.question: Q5
